questions.neutral: Did you time it well - calm right now?

hobby.message: Antique typewriters and quiet bars — good pair.
Any new mods on your FPV quad?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Bit of quiet is rare. I don't mind it.
I do a little street photography in my spare time.
Not much inspiration out there these days.
Checkpoints make it complicated.
Yeah, decent timing. I needed a breather after today.
Used to shoot film around the city for fun.
Now, checkpoints mess with my routes and timing.
Getting decent shots is a struggle lately.
Not worth the risk sometimes.
Feels calm, but surface isn't real these days.
I sneak out with an old 35mm camera, street shots on film.
Used to love dusk in District 5, people everywhere.
Since the new biometric checks, whole scene's changed.
Last week, drones ruined three of my best photos.
Still—sometimes you get lucky. One good shot makes it worthwhile.
Quiet now, but only because people are exhausted.
I'm addicted to film photography, real street moments, nothing staged.
Tried shooting near the new checkpoints last week—total surveillance zone.
Drones, ID scans, the whole mood changed, people paranoid.
One BCI warning mid-shoot nearly made me trash my camera.
But when I caught a kid glaring back at me, fearless?
That image feels like why I do this.
You read the room well—these nights are rare now.
Ever since I was a kid, I've sworn by 35mm film—real grain, no filters.
Shooting candid street scenes worked before the crackdowns.
Last week, checkpoints and BCI surveillance nearly got me flagged for nothing.
I'm barely hanging on with a score of 22. Even walking around with a camera gets you profiled.
Developed my shots anyway—almost all wrecked by nerves except one, a kid refusing to look away.
Holding onto that—it's proof not everything's been erased yet.
Not sure how long it lasts, but I'm not quitting.
hobby_answer: Still is. I keep it close.
Film’s hard to get with all these new controls.
Snapped a few shots last week, checkpoints everywhere.
Most nights I stay home now. Too many eyes.
It isn’t as easy as it used to be.
Always. Nothing digital beats real film.
But the Directorate’s new checkpoints make it risky.
Nearly lost a roll last weekend to those new scanners.
The air’s different out there. People watch; no one talks.
You really have to pick your moments now.
One slip, and your BCI drops even more.
It’s my lifeline. Still running film, even in this climate.
Went out after curfew last week. Drones, checkpoints, you name it.
Used to blend in, now every move feels marked.
Met a kid by the scanners, caught a shot. Felt dangerous.
Most frames were trash—hands shaking, too many patrols.
Makes every print matter more, you know?
Even seeing real faces is rare these days.
Always my weapon. Analog film tells what algorithms can’t see.
Been dodging those biometric posts every session now.
Used to roam alleys free—now the city’s a neural net.
Last Saturday, caught a real moment: a girl glaring at patrols.
The ghosts’ stories make people glance at the lens, just in case.
My BCI dipped so low, doors lock for me at work.
Honestly, shooting feels illegal now, but it’s worth it.
Sometimes I think the camera’s my last real voice.
Always has been, always will. Dad taught me in secret, back before BCI.
I smuggle in rolls, develop at home—can’t trust labs with this climate.
When Halden died, the city flipped. Drones everywhere, checkpoints at every turn.
Last Sunday, tried capturing fear at the scanners. BCI drop hit instantly.
Colleagues avoid me now—too risky to be seen sharing footage.
Bar 101’s the only place I dare speak honest about it.
Sometimes I sneak prints to ghosts, help them prove they exist.
The world’s become an archive dusted by algorithms. I settle for stolen frames.
If they ever catch me, at least I’ll have the negatives.
